channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus in the U.S: Live News and Updates
item.description: For renters who’ve survived financially with help from the government and laws barring eviction, time is running out. Despite analysts’ forecasts, investors keep pushing the stock market higher.
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emma Witbolsfeugen stood on the shoulder of I-70 in Independence, Mo., to rally for rent forgiveness.

item.title: Scattered to the Winds, College Students Mourn Lost Semester
item.description: The unpredictability of life during the pandemic has been hard on everyone, but it has caused particular stress for many college students.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maite Rodriguez inside her home, above her family’s restaurant, Maite Sports Bar and Pub, in Newark.

item.title: An ‘Avalanche of Evictions’ Could Be Bearing Down on America’s Renters
item.description: The economic downturn is shaping up to be particularly devastating for renters, who are more likely to be lower-income and work hourly jobs cut during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sandy Naffah in her apartment in Euclid, Ohio, with her dog, Shadow. Ms. Naffah is worried about eviction after losing two part-time jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: George Floyd Video and Other Bystander Footage Are Policing the Police
item.description: The initial police account of the death of a Minneapolis man did not mention that an officer’s knee pinned him to the ground. “Please, I can’t breathe,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch and John Eligon
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Flores/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A memorial in Minneapolis for George Floyd, who died after being taken into custody by the police. A bystander’s video shared widely on Tuesday showed an officer pressing his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck.

item.title: Big Pharmacy Chains Also Fed the Opioid Epidemic, Court Filing Says
item.description: New details emerge in a lawsuit asserting that chains including CVS, Rite Aid and Walgreens sold millions of pills in small towns but rarely flagged suspicious orders to authorities.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: CVS, which operates thousands of pharmacies, worked with manufacturers to promote opioids as safe and effective, according to a new court filing.

item.title: Trump Plays the Old Conspiracy Theory Hits
item.description: Trump smears Joe Scarborough, and Twitter does a voting fact-check: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: The Persistence of Police Killings
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jenna Watson/Indianapolis Star, via Associated Press

item.title: When the Mexican Air Force Went to War Alongside America
item.description: In 1945, the 201st Mexican Fighter Squadron helped the U.S. Army Air Forces defeat Japan — significantly changing relations between the two allies after the war.
item.dc:creator: Richard Parker
item.media:description: Members of the 201st Fighter Squadron of the Mexican Expeditionary Air Force, which was attached to the Fifth Air Force during World War II, at Clark Field in the Philippines.

item.title: Meet Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley, SpaceX’s First NASA Astronauts
item.description: They’re best friends and veterans of the astronaut corps, and each is married to another astronaut.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The astronauts Robert L. Behnken, left, and Douglas G. Hurley, donning their spacesuits during a dress rehearsal of SpaceX’s uncrewed In-Flight Abort Test in January.

item.title: For Steve King, the Number of People Who Want Him Gone Could Be a Blessing
item.description: The Iowa congressman, known for his racist remarks about immigrants, is an outcast among mainstream Republicans. But his four primary challengers could split the vote.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:description: Representative Steve King of Iowa was removed from his committee assignments after he told The New York Times, “White nationalist, white supremacist, Western civilization — how did that language become offensive?”

item.title: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: An assembly line that produces both the electric vehicle Renault Zoe and the hybrid vehicle Nissan Micra in France this month.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Pandemic Global Updates
item.description: France revoked the authorization for hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for Covid-19 patients. The rise of virus-tracking apps in China is stirring privacy fears.
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing tables to serve customers in Milan this month.

item.title: SpaceX Launch: How and When to Watch to Today
item.description: What you need to know about the mission taking two NASA astronauts to the space station on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A SpaceX rocket with the Crew Dragon capsule on top as it was raised onto the launchpad on Tuesday at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

item.title: Michigan Governor Says Husband’s Request Was ‘Failed Attempt at Humor’
item.description: A business owner said Marc Mallory had pointed out that he was married to Gov. Gretchen Whitmer while asking if the company could move his boat sooner.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer in Midland, Mich., this month.

item.title: Jimmy Fallon Apologizes for Blackface Skit
item.description: In a ‘Saturday Night Live’ sketch from 2000, Mr. Fallon appears in blackface while impersonating his fellow comedian Chris Rock.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Fallon in February. “There is no excuse for this,” Mr. Fallon said of the blackface sketch.

item.title: Will Twitter Draw a Line for Trump?
item.description: Kara Swisher says President Trump is an expert at gaming Twitter, but the company can still step in.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: House to Vote on Limiting F.B.I. Power to Collect Americans’ Internet Data
item.description: Lawmakers compromised on an ambiguously worded amendment that narrows a failed but popular Senate proposal.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: The House had passed a version of a FISA overhaul bill in March, and the Senate has voted on several amendments.

item.title: Twitter Refutes Inaccuracies in Trump’s Tweets About Mail-In Voting
item.description: Twitter added a link to two of President Trump’s tweets in which he had made false claims about mail-in ballots, urging people to “get the facts.”
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Davey Alba
item.media:description: Jack Dorsey, the chief executive of Twitter, has come under scrutiny over the company’s handling of tweets from President Trump.

item.title: Union Insists Actors Shouldn’t Work Till Epidemic Is ‘Under Control’
item.description: Actors’ Equity Association, which represents 51,000 theater performers and stage managers, lays out guidelines aimed to keep its members safe.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Kate Shindle, president of Actors' Equity Association, addressing the media at a virtual news conference that included the union’s medical adviser, Dr. David Michaels.

item.title: Britain, Host of U.N. Climate Talks, Proposes Full-Year Pandemic Delay
item.description: The postponement, expected to be approved, could result in national recovery plans with high environmental costs, some diplomats say.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Alok Sharma, the British cabinet secretary responsible for the Glasgow climate conference.

item.title: A New Conundrum for Fact-Checking Trump on Twitter
item.description: The social media company came under fire — again — for not removing Mr. Trump’s posts that contain falsehoods.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Davey Alba
item.media:description: President Trump has recently tweeted false conspiracy theories about the 2001 death of Lori Klausutis.

item.title: Republicans Sue Pelosi to Block House Proxy Voting During Pandemic
item.description: The suit filed by Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, opens a new front in Republicans’ push to throw suspicion on Democratic efforts to make it easier to vote amid the outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy has called the new rules a “power grab.”

item.title: In Audacious Move, Georgia and Florida Governors Offer to Host G.O.P. Convention
item.description: The party is still contractually obligated to hold the event in North Carolina, but President Trump has threatened a change of location as the state’s Democratic governor urges caution because of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Ethan Hyman/The News & Observer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina at a briefing last week. He said on Tuesday, “I will say that it’s OK for political conventions to be political, but pandemic response cannot be.”

item.title: Justice Dept. Ends Inquiries Into 3 Senators’ Stock Trades
item.description: Law enforcement officials told three senators that they would not be pursuing charges, but an investigation into trades by Senator Richard Burr of North Carolina appears to be proceeding.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:description: Senator Kelly Loeffler, Republican of Georgia, and her husband reported transactions worth millions of dollars beginning in late January, right after senators received their first private briefing from top health officials on Covid-19.

item.title: Hunger Program’s Slow Start Leaves Millions of Children Waiting
item.description: Child hunger is soaring, but two months after Congress approved billions to replace school meals, only 15 percent of eligible children had received benefits.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: City workers handed out meals to parents in Santa Clara, Calif.

item.title: Supreme Court Refuses to Stop Order to Move Inmates From Virus-Ravaged Prison
item.description: The court’s action left in place a court order requiring prison officials to move more than 800 older or medically vulnerable prisoners from a facility that has seen nine deaths from Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: The Supreme Court’s brief, unsigned order turned in part on a procedural issue.

item.title: Longtime Pentagon Watchdog Stepping Down From Post
item.description: President Trump had ousted the official last month from a new role overseeing the administration’s spending of pandemic relief money.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Charlie Savage and Noah Weiland
item.media:description: Glenn A. Fine cited the importance of the inspectors general throughout the government.

item.title: A Socially Distanced Las Vegas? What Are the Odds?
item.description: Will a stripped-down version of the city attract the same number of visitors who used to come to party at pools, dance in nightclubs and gamble in casinos?
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration of how blackjack could work with barriers at the El Cortez Hotel and Casino.

item.title: After Crowding at Lake of the Ozarks, Missouri Officials Urge Quarantine
item.description: “It’s irresponsible and dangerous to engage in such high risk behavior just to have some fun over the extended holiday weekend,” said the mayor of St. Louis.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin and Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: People celebrated Memorial Day weekend at Lake of the Ozarks in Missouri.

item.title: Could All Those ‘Quarantinis’ Lead to Drinking Problems?
item.description: Addiction specialists said it was possible for people who are drinking heavily and consistently during the coronavirus pandemic to develop a problem they did not have before.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: A virtual happy hour.

item.title: Trump Pushes a Conspiracy Theory That Falsely Accuses a TV Host of Murder
item.description: On Twitter and at a news conference, the president said Joe Scarborough was responsible for the death of Lori Klausutis, who worked for him when he was a congressman. But Twitter refused her husband’s request to have the false tweets removed.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Maggie Astor
item.media:description: President Trump has repeatedly promoted a conspiracy theory as part of a long-running attack on Joe Scarborough.

item.title: Trump Bolsters Staff for Election With New Deputy Campaign Manager
item.description: The president is installing Bill Stepien, a veteran political adviser, to the top hierarchy of his re-election staff, adding support for the campaign manager, Brad Parscale.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bill Stepien boarding Air Force One in October 2018.

item.title: ‘I Can’t Breathe’: 4 Minneapolis Officers Fired After Black Man Dies in Custody
item.description: “Being black in America should not be a death sentence,” the city’s mayor said as video of the arrest was widely shared.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: George Floyd
